Name: Spelling Bee
Description: Spelling Bee is a game of making words from a deck of single-letter cards.  On each turn, a player must either start a new word, play a card on an existing word to make a new word, or pass.  Letters can be added at the front, back, or anywhere inside a word already on the table.  The winner is the player with the fewest cards remaining in their hand when all players have passed.

Name: Little Bear: Berries, Cherries, Apples & Pears
Description:
Kids can help Little Bear & his friends stroll through the orchard to gather fruit for their picnic!!  The first player to pick up all their fruit wins!

It's a fun way for children to recognize colors and improve counting and sequencing skills.  Plus, they learn cooperation and team-building along the way!

(from box)

Name: Panzer PaK 3: Normandy to Berlin
Description:
The decisive battles around Arracourt commenced on 15 September 1944 when elements of the German 15th Panzer Grenadier Division clashed with the reconnaissance units of the USA 2nd Cavalry Group. After initially withdrawing, the Germans again advanced near the town of Luneville, with the 111th Panzer Brigade committed as reinforcements.

Panzer PaK 3 covers the fighting from the allied landing at Normandy until VE Day. All forty American unit cards are included in this expansion, along with three scenarios and the organizations for Wehrmarcht and US Army forces on the western front.

Panzer PaK 3 is an expansion to Panzer Miniatures Rules: A Tactical Game of Armored Combat.

Included Components:


     Scenarios — Three historical scenarios focusing on Operation Cobra



     Detailed US Army TO&E: General organizations from 1942 until 1945 — includes Heavy and Light Armored Divisions, Infantry Division, and Airborne Division to the individual vehicle, gun and squad level



     Optional Rule: Hidden movement rules for Panzer



     Unit Data Cards: 40 new unit data cards (completes USA units)



     Hidden Movement Cards: two hidden movement play cards


Expands:

    Panzer Miniatures Rules: A Tactical Game of Armored Combat

Name: Bible Anagrams
Description:
"A Bible-centered word building game for ages 9 and up."

A Scrabble-like board and letter tiles is used by a "Leader" to form five to eleven words related to the Bible, face-down except for the first letter.  Each square on the board has one, two, or three dots.  Players have tokens that move around the letters of the alphabet that encircle the board.  These letters have a numerical value associated with each, with (like Scrabble) the less often used letters having a higher value.

On their turn, players guess a letter in a single word, but are restricted to guessing the letter their token is on or one of the next seven letters.  The Leader moderates.  Players get points based on the value of the letter correctly guessed times the number of dots in the square it rests on.  Players may move their token ahead seven letters around the board instead of guessing, to get within range of a letter they want to guess.

The Leader keeps score, and the leading scorer when all the words are guessed wins.

Name: Congo Line
Description:
Congo Line is a game where goods move from city to city across the Congo.  During each turn, players will chose whether to load their goods onto a train or move a train toward the next city.  Players also have the opportunity to purchase stock in the train companies as well.
 When a train reaches the next city, stocks and goods are converted into money.  At the end of the game, the player with the most money wins!  As the trains travel along the tracks, however, they are at risk of being robbed.  Similarly, the stockholders are subject to being bought out or of seeing the value of their stock diminish!  
 Each game includes board, a 5-page rule set, dice, cubes for goods, stock tokens, chips, and train pieces.
Families: Country: Democratic Republic of the Congo

Name: D! Bone
Description:
D! Bone is a card game that combines the 5 point scoring system of Dominoes with the Spreads, Hits, and Wild Cards of Rummy. D! Bone uses special 2" x 3" cards designed exclusively for this game.

It takes a couple of hands to learn the rules,after that it's all about winning! If you're looking for a challenge, if you like creating strategy, and if you like winning, you will have hours of fun playing D! Bone!

2 to 4 players, ages 10 to adult

Name: Jeu de la Révolution Française
Description:
A race game for any number of players taking place on a board depicting events of the French Revolution. The game was produced during the revolution, apparently for propaganda purposes.

Players advance from the fall of the Bastille towards the National Assembly. Players landing on certain spaces are required to pay tokens and/or suffer other penalties. Players falling into the well must await rescue by another player. A player in prison must await another player to take his place. A player landing on the Death square must return to the start. The winner is the first player to land on the final space, by exact count.

Name: Island Hopping
Description:
Island Hopping is how you get around in The Bahamas!  And it's also a lively game of strategy and chance.  As you play, you'll explore the country's beautiful islands and discover places you'd like to go.

You win the game by stacking four similar coins on one island.  But as you develop your winning strategy, remember that your best-laid plans can be sidetracked as the game takes you to unexpected destinations!

Name: Féodalité
Description:
Féodalité is a Medieval Strategic level Card-Driven board-wargame for 2 players, published in Vae Victis issue #69.

A combination of map and card game which simulates the Capetian Kingdoms after the death of Charlemagne (9th and 10th centuries).
Families: Players: Wargames with Rules Supporting Only Two Players

Name: Opération Pedestal
Description: Opération Pedestal, published in Vae Victis issue #69 as a bonus solitaire-only mini-wargame, simulates the attack on Operation Pedestal in August 1942, of a convoy bound for Malta.  The player takes on the role of the Axis and must sink as many ships as possible, primarily  tankers.

Name: Superman Returns: Kryptonite Crisis
Description: Based on the 2006 film Superman Returns, this game challenges players to be the first to defeat Lex Luthor by reaching the top of New Krypton. A 3D board and rolling Kryptonite boulders add to the challenge. Each turn involves four phases: Draw a card; Roll the die and take the appropriate action; Play cards; Discard down to 5 cards. The recommended age is 6+ and this game is a notch above most licensed games designed for such young children.

Name: Fidchell: Celtic Chess
Description: Played on a polar grid with variable numbers of positions on each circumference. One piece-type only (stones), each player starts with 27 stones, 8 placed at specific starting positions, 19 off board. Two game phases : placement and then movement. Play usually alternates between players. Custodian capture applies during each phase, successful capture allows a second move. The two players have asymmetric goals, however: white must build a continuous line of pieces from center to circumference, black must prevent this from happening.

Name: Le Jeu de Jet
Description:
Truly like no other board game; like nothing else around, above, below or underneath, Le Jeu de Jet is a Battle game for 2 players fought over a number of Rounds between their Houses where the winner is the player who takes "prisoner" all of their opponents set of 18 pieces, called Woods.
   
Taking turns, players choose Woods from their Maison table  then shake them in their hand, or in a cup, & then throw them down into the Battle circle. These are now divided according to how they land, to be secretly built (stacked) into Houses in whatever way the player chooses ready for Battle; & that's when the real fun begins! Recommended Ages 9+

Name: Flight
Description:
This is a simple but addictive 2 to 4 players race game (no dice are used) where the players ’fly’ their men across the board, racing to be the first to bear off all his men from the board.

In this game the players men are called Merels.

If you jump your opponent’s Merels, you go again; If you jump your own Merels, then you go again! So fly across the board in a single strike, or block & wait for a better opportunity in this multi-color, multi-level, multi-player race game! Recommended Ages 7+

Name: Checkout Game: 4 Square Food-Market Shopping Game
Description:
Checkout
The first shopper to spin and match the number in his checkout counter aisle twice, once for each numbered square, checks-out of the store first and wins the game.
Comes with lots of (96) cute little vintage product cards such as Weet-Bix, Marmite, Edmonds Baking Powder, Pedigree Dolls. 
Also comes with 4 plastic shopping carts used as playing pieces. 
Instructions on lid of box.

Name: Bunker Hill
Description: Bunker Hill. Battle of the American Revolution. Card Game for 2 players. Separate Decks for the Americans & British. Cards represent Leaders, Troops, Fortifications, Shooting, Strategies, and Blunders. Unique Turn Sequencing results in Multiple possible Victory Conditions and Outcomes.

Name: Ætherverse: Upheaval
Description:
Ætherverse: Upheaval. Upheaval is a new, fast-paced game of small skirmish combat, set in the cities of the parallel universes of Ætherverse. Upheaval features an exciting campaign system, giving players new strategic choices as they guide a band of green troops through battle after battle, guiding their experiences and upgrading their abilities and equipment until they either become an elite force or are destroyed and replaced by new green troops.

Available exclusively in digital download format, Upheaval is a 48-page PDF written by Jason Lauborough, designer of the original Ætherverse and featuring art and fiction from the Ætherverse print rulebook. The game leverages aspects of the revolutionary Ætherverse army design system to provide a highly flexible upgrade path for units as they progress through the game. The gameplay portion of Upheaval features a revised and pared-down version of the Ætherverse rules, optimized for small-skirmish play between two to four small units of troops (roughly 8-30 models per army).

Upheaval is suitable for sci-fi play of military or "gang warfare" variety, historical and modern skirmishes, and fantasy war band campaigning. The PDF also contains options for adding even more detail to your campaigns, as well as providing rules for creating units that are already experienced, allowing for "one-off" games to be played between interesting armies without having to go through a full campaign system.

Upheaval's gameplay rules are ideal for 2-4 players, and the campaign system supports as many players as desired.

Upheaval is fully supported by the Triskelegames.com website, including an active forum community, and will receive periodic free updates through the release of the semi-monthly Æthergate Newsletter.

Name: A Simple Civil War Game Deluxe
Description:
A SIMPLE CIVIL WAR GAME DELUXE © 2004
Simple wargame rules for re-fighting the Battle of Gettysburg
Game includes:

16-page rule book
32-page Armies of Gettysburg (Ratings for all regiments and leaders)
50 card movement and firing deck of cards (using Avery Business Card Template 5377)
Full Color cover sheet with “Grand Battery” errata on reverse side 
Players Aid sheet, 1- unit record sheet, and 1-sheet of game tables.

This simple tabletop game can be played with any Civil War miniatures you may have, or with something as simple as a set of wooden blocks painted blue and gray.

Combat is based on the “stand” (each stand representing 100 men, or 2 guns and crew)

Movement, combat, and morale are based (and modified) for the levels of command.
In these rules, leaders can make a real difference when units of equal capability and morale meet on the table-top. Card draw effects movement, combat, and time.

The 16-page rule book is easy to learn as the rule is on the left side of the page, and a photo, illustration, or highlight is on the right side of the page to clarify that rule or statement.

The 32-page “armies” booklet that rates each regiment, battery, and officer in the Army of the Potomac and Army of Northern Virginia for their performance during the Battle of Gettysburg and is organized by the UNION Corp or CONFEDERATE Division

1-set of 50 cards that control time, firing, movement, and “special situations” that might occur during a table-top battle. Each cycle of the deck is “1-hour” of game time.

These rules can use any of your existing miniatures, stand size makes no difference as long as both sides are mounted the same. If you do not have miniatures, or do not want to paint miniatures, a product called “ACW Paper Armies” is available for both sides. Individual “stands” show infantry, cavalry, artillery, commanders, wagons, and limbers in full color overhead photos.

Name: Aces at Dawn
Description:
In August of 1914, the airplane had barely made its tenth anniversary, and had only just become a weapon of war. The Italians had used air power (if it could be called that) in North Africa in 1911, and Louis Blériot’s famous trip across the English Channel was still a fresh memory.

The Great War was a time of heroes and villains, a war where everyone knew who was fighting whom and for what cause. Both sides had their great victories, huge defeats and plenty of trench foot. While this game is designed to simulate the greatest battles over the trenches of the World War I battlefield, we should not forget that men and women died for their beliefs and for their countries. Heroes were born of this combat on both sides.

At no other time in our warring history has there been such a change as the airplane. Not only did combat change forever once our soldiers were airborne, but a whole generation became enamored of this newest weapon in our military arsenal. Even into the twenty-first century, the romance and joys of those first years in the air evoke the deepest respect for these new knights, these men of the airways.
Aces at Dawn is a game of quasi-historical combat in the skies. Set at the turn of the century, the game models the man-to-man combat of the World-War I flying ace and his dreaded enemies. As with all Majestic Twelve games, Aces at Dawn is fun and easy to play, works with any line of miniatures, and encourages players to use their imagination and have fun, which is the way wargaming is supposed to be.

With 36 planes at your disposal and a fully-customizable points system, you can build existing planes we haven't included and also try out designs that you think would have wreaked havoc in the skies of France.

The flexibility of the system allows players to recreate the man-to-man air jousting at the turn of the twentieth century. A simple combat and maneuver system means you can dispense with complicated maneuver charts and intricately detailed plane record-keeping. What’s left on the board is just plain fun.

The ZIP file includes both full-color and printer-friendly PDF versions of the rulebook.

Name: Iron Stars: Southern Front
Description:
Southern Front is the second supplement for Iron Stars, the game of space combat in an age of steam and steel. In this book players will find additional game mechanics and background material that extends our semi historical timeline through the pivotal year of 1912:


     An overview of world history from the close of the Merchant War through the Antarctic crisis;
     Nearly four dozen new ether ship designs, covering the space forces of South America, Italy, Turkey, and Spain, along with additional ships from Britain and Japan, and the introduction of the Soviet space forces;
     Coverage of the Falklands War between the British Empire and the A.B.C. Powers (Argentina, Brazil, and Chile), including nine new scenarios;
     "The Red One”, a short story by Jack London;
     A new space station, HMSS Diamond Rock;
     Rules for boarding parties and shipboard combat;
     New special equipment, such as star shells and heat rays; and
     Rules for orbital bombardment of surface targets.


This should be more than enough to keep your ether navies occupied as the world marches inexorably towards the Great War.

Southern Front includes nine (9) sheets of counters and templates for use with star shells and orbital bombardment.

Name: Nobel
Description: Nobel is a world peace game. The goal is simple. Achieve world peace. In order to succeed, players must disarm all the countries featured on Nobel's map of the world. The winner is the player who has gathered the most world peace doves at the game's end. He received the Nobel Peace Prize of the world Peace Game. All things considered, the game is about missiles, disarmament and world peace treaties.

Name: Apples to Apples: Party Box Expansion TWO
Description:
This is yet another expansion for the great party game.  According to the manufacturers, it is equivalent to 2 other expansion sets, which would otherwise have been numbered #5 and #6

From Apples to Apples description:
Definitely designed for groups of non-gamers (not necessarily a bad thing), Apples to Apples consists only of two decks of cards: Things and Descriptions. Each turn, the current referee selects a Description and players try to pick, from the cards in their hands, the Things that best match that Description. The referee then chooses the Thing that appeals to him most and awards the card to the player who played it. The unusual combinations of Things and Descriptions are humorous to the extreme, and will quickly have the entire room in an uproar. Once someone has won a pre-determined number of cards, he's the winner.

Part of the Apples to Apples Series.

Name: Bing-Oh!
Description:
This is the CRAZIEST bingo game you'll ever play!

Choose your Bing-Oh!™ card at random. Each one is different.

Take turns rolling the Bing-Oh!™ dice. Place your chips on the corresponding space and let the MADNESS begin!

Depending on the square your chip lands on, you may get to steal chips from your opponent, add extra chips to your card, lose a turn, roll again, swap cards with an opponent, set up a “Road Block”, or one of many other devious events.

Get six in a row to win, but be careful! Your opponent might foil your victory by removing chips from your board! Or worse yet, you might run out of chips!

There is no telling what’s gonna happen next in Bing-Oh!™
Families: Versions & Editions: Dice Versions of Non-Dice Games

Name: Do Over!
Description:
The game of second chances

Do Over!™ is the fast paced game where everything can change at a moment’s notice. Just when you think you have your opponent right where you want them, it’s a “Do Over!” Look out for the “bomb” card, as it will level the payload you were about to unleash on your foe! Be the first to get rid of your cards to claim victory.

Try playing Do Over!™ just once - it’s a game you’ll want to “Do Over” again and again!

Name: Dos Trios
Description:
From the dusty outposts of the Argentinian plains to the wilderness of Bolivia’s Altiplano, Dos Trios™ is the classic card game that has kept South American gauchos and señoritas entertained for generations. Relive yesteryear with the rich, linen finish of these authentic cards.

Dos Trios™ is a real thinker’s game - there’s no room for simple luck here! You’ll need to use strategy, cunning, and nerves to play your best hand. Each round has a different objective! Be careful how you play - don’t be too quick to show your hand, or your opponent will surely take advantage!

Name: Combat Dominoes
Description:
Combat Dominoes is a battle against the enemy's dominating dominoes in order to build a base and gain intelligence.  Infantry and special-ops dominoes are used in the fight to defeat the enemy in the domino warfare action.

Game play is similar to traditional domino games like All-Fives. The player with the highest double places it on the table facing horizontally. This becomes a separator that divides each player's base. On their turn, each player can place a domino only on their side of the divider, unless the other player runs out of viable plays, in which case their base becomes open to invasion by the opposing player.

Dominoes with blank ends have unique special-ops graphics printed on them. When special-ops dominoes are played, one of several events can occur, such as swapping domino tiles with the opposing player, or engaging in domino "combat."

The first player to shed all their dominoes wins the round. Points are tallied by adding up the number of pips from the dominoes still remaining in the loser's hand. The first player to accumulate 100 points wins the game.

Name: Cars: Tractor Tipping Game
Description:
From the Manufacturer:
The Disney/Pixar movie, CARS, introduces original and lovable characters that kids will love, and with the Tractor Tipping board game, kids can recreate the fun of a favorite pastime in Radiator Springs, tractor tipping. Players race around the pasture board scaring tractors, being careful not to wake up Frank the Combine or they will lose points and have to go back to the starting line. Each tractor tips over to reveal points beneath each of them! The first person to collect seven points wins.

Name: Rommel at Gazala
Description:
Rommel at Gazala is a quick-playing game with a simple, accessible system.  It is sufficiently easy for new players to enter board wargaming, but with enough possibilities to offer significant replay value to newcomer and veteran player alike.  Counter density is low, letting the players concentrate on strategy more than minutiae, and the pace is fast.  There are also special rules to evoke the special flavor of the battle; armor superiority, the dreaded "88," fortifications, and of course the special capabilities of Erwin Rommel himself.

COMPONENTS

1 8.5" x 17" Color Map (In Three Sections for Easy Printing)
1 Sheet of 66 Backprinted Counters (Mounting Required)
1 16-Page Rulebook
1 24-Page Battle Manual, With Designer's Notes, Historical Background, and More
1 Terrain Effects Chart
1 Player's Aid Card

Not to be confused with the game of same name published in 1995.  This is a new game.  Published as a DTP (Desktop Publishing) game, the game consists of PDF files that must be printed and mounted (the counters, if desired) before playing.

Nominee for the 2006 Charles S. Roberts awards for Best DTP-Produced Boardgame (Charles S. Roberts Awards).

Name: Master of Venice
Description:
Master of Venice. Game of Renaissance Intrigue. You are a Merchant Family of Great Wealth & Prestige. Amass your Fortune by sending out your Cogs & Caravans along well Established Trade Routes. Buy Cardinals and Senators. Bid carefully in the Elections to gain control of the Doge and Pope. Beware Pirates, Plagues, Crusades, and Excommunications. All resources have a cost, and all have vulnerabilities. Game rules and card set available at: 
http://www.angelfire.com/games2/warpspawn/MOV.html

Name: SuperSystem (Second Edition)
Description:
SuperSystem 2nd Edition brings the action of comic book battles back to your tabletop with faster, cleaner rules, and a comprehensive list of powers and special effects that will allow players to build any character they can imagine. Extensive write-ups of over 100 official characters and henchmen groups make starting a game easy.

Designed to work with the SuperFigs line of 28mm Super miniatures, SuperSystem provides a flexible setting and campaign rules that will allow players to further develop stories and characters with each scenario played.

100 pages, including full color covers, index, counters, and other play aids.

Expanded by:

    SuperSystem 2007 Annual

Name: Babylon's Burning
Description:
Babylon's Burning is a near-future, post-apocalyptic skirmish game combining a gritty, atmospheric setting with rules that are both easy to learn and highly realistic.

The year is 2025 - 10 years after the Hit, the catastrophic meteor impact that tore society apart and set in motion a chain of events that left cities in ruins and 95% of the world's population dead and buried under a blanket of dust and ash. The survivors have banded together for mutual protection, resources are scarce and every other group is either a threat or an obstacle.
The background of the Babylon's Burning game is it's core - not a few paragraphs tagged on to the rules as an afterthought. You're introduced into the game with an extensive history of the Hit and an overview of the world of 2025 and drawn in further with the extensive fiction and the beautifully rendered and atmospheric original artwork that appears throughout.

The game mechanics are detailed but intuitive. This is a skirmish level game suitable for anything from a handful of troops to forty or so miniatures per side. Squads, solo elements (officers, snipers, medics and runners) and support weapons move according to a variable initiative system - there is no waiting around twiddling your thumbs while your opponent moves their entire force and the system is perfect for games with more than 2 players.

While it uses a fictional setting, Babylon's Burning recognizes the realities of modern combat. In order to come out on top, players need to keep moving, pick their targets well, take advantage of suppression and, most of all, utilize the terrain of tomorrow's shattered cities. This is a game that rewards players who ask themselves "what would I do?" - pushing blindly forward in tight formations is a good way to get very dead, very quickly.
Another advantage of the realistic setting is that there are no "super units" - in the confines of a dark alley, a nail-studded baseball bat is as deadly a weapon as any other...

The game accommodates a wide selection of faction types - Enclaves, Street Gangs, Mercs, Scavs, Ghouls, Culties, Mobs and Syndicates - all of them complete with their own restrictions and advantages. These factions don't just look different; they play differently too. From well armed Enclave militia built around a crack corps of pre-Hit professionals to street kid gangs moving about the table with dizzying speed on skateboards and roller blades, Babylon's Burning allows the player to choose the faction that best reflects their style of play.

FEATURES -

100 pages - looks great in color or black and white
Full-color counters and burst templates
Quick reference sheet and record sheets
Extensive scene-setting fiction by Jay Forster
Beautiful artwork by Elena Vanin, Jim Campbell and Craig Humpston

REVIEWS -

"The first thing to strike me was the very well produced and laid out format…the rules themselves are well thought out [with] plenty of examples interspersed in the text [and] are framed by an engrossing piece of fiction.

The best point of the rules is simply the fact that they are generic in their outlook - they are intended for use with any figures on the market, so they are not bound to a specific company's miniatures. This is a bonus, because you can use any figures you want, unlike some systems that insist on the sole use of 'official' figures."
(From the WARGAMES DIRECTORY review)

"The background material is very plausible and I think well researched as to the possibilities of this occurrence actually happening. I’ll not go into details about the background but lets just say it is indeed refreshing from the old nuclear exchange routine and I do think quite believable.

Gives a multitude of campaign and scenario options…the gaming possibilities are endless and I have admiration for these guys for the concept being a quite in depth look at what could happen in the near future, and I surmise a lot of thought and research must have gone into the whole planning of the background."
(From the WARGAMES FORUM review)

"We've been playing it, and loving it. The game is complex, detailed and easy to learn."
(From the APOCALYPSE FICTION review)

"Well produced and nicely laid out...the rules are supplied with a hefty set of appendices detailing the various forces that battle within the futuristic world of Babylon's Burning. There is no need to go out and buy an army book. There is plenty of choice here to keep you interested."
(From the MINIATURE REVIEW review)

Name: Familie Seebrück
Description:
The family is suspected of having  murdered the daughter of the prominent brewery owner. Is there really a murder in the family Seebrück?

All players (4 male, 4 female (+ 1 m/f)) should act out their role to solve the mystery, because one of the guests is the murderer

Name: Ice Age 2: Mammal Crossing
Description:
From the publisher:
Kids will love the challenges of the Ice Age 2 Mammal Crossing Board Game. They'll embark on adventures with their favorite characters - trying to dodge rocks, serpents and geysers to get to safety! Be the first to reach the other side of the valley to win. Comes with four sculpted and painted character movers.

Name: Piece Packing Pirates
Description:
Ahoy, me hearties! Thar's booty afloat, and me wants me fair share. The sea, she's a-callin' me, so drink ye grog and woo ye lassies tonight, for on th' morrow it's gangplanks and cutlasses. We weigh anchor at dawn!

Piece Packing Pirates is a solitaire sea adventure full of sailing, booty, fighting, booty, mayhem and more booty! The game is playable with a standard piecepack set.

Winner of the piecepack Solitary Confinement design contest.

Name: Tumble Words
Description:
Seemingly another game similar to Perquackey or Scrabble Crossword Cubes Game.  May predate both of them.

Tumble Words  is a word dice game.

Name: Sea Hunt Underwater Adventure Game
Description: Sea Hunt Underwater Adventure Game is based on an old TV show from the late 1950's and early 1960's called "Sea Hunt" that starred Lloyd Bridges as Mike Nelson a skin diver. This game was made by Lowell Toy MFG. Corp., New York 56, N.Y. The copyright is listed as 1961 Ziv-United Artists, Inc. This is a spin and move game. The object of the game is to search areas of the sea for gold treasure.

Name: Big Trouble
Description: Electronic talking Pop-o-Matic Trouble bubble "tells" you whether to discard or add cards to your hand with colorful lights and fun sound effects. Be the first player to discard your hand of cards and win the game! Includes Trouble bubble and deck of cards.

Name: Kenshin vs Shingen: Battle of Kawanakajima
Description:
This game simulates the clash between Takeda Shingen and Uesugi Kenshin that took place near the Kawanakajima plains on September 10th, 1561 (1561 being Eiroku 4 in the calendar system of the time). This was the 4th, and greatest (yet still inconclusive) of the battles of Kawanakajima.

Many previous wargames use luck of the dice to determine the results of combat, but this game instead has players choose one of their combat cards, numbered 1-6, to resolve battles. Because of this, victory is determined not by the 'random factor' of one's luck with dice, but with 'reading and bluffing'.

Name: Hundred Days Campaign
Description:
This game covers Napoleon at Waterloo.

Many previous wargames use luck of the dice to determine the results of combat, but this game instead has players choose one of their combat cards, with modifiers equivalent to dice rolling, to resolve battles. Because of this, victory is determined not by the 'random factor' of one's luck with dice, but with 'reading and bluffing'.

Name: Die Nasionale Kruger-Wildtuin
Description: In Die Nasionale Kruger-Wildtuin (aka The Kruger National Park) players take a tour of the Kruger National Park in South Africa, where the object is take photographs of as many animals as possible before visiting your three campsites and exiting the park.

Name: Flits de Muis
Description:
A game where a player tries to get the wooden mouse as fast as possible to its destination in the food chips, while another player tries to solve the dexterity game. If the player gets the food before, he gets to keep it.

Fritz der Mäuseblitz is a game for children 6 to 12. There is a board with squares between the mouse hole and the pantry. Each round, a player plays the mouse and his/her left neighbor tries simultaneously to catch the mouse. After each turn, roles turn clockwise. The player with the mouse rolls a D6 die and moves the mouse from the hole to the pantry and back to get food. Simultaneously, the other player tries to put 2 mouses in 2 traps in a tiny dexterity game. If he succeeds before the mouse reaches the pantry, he gets 2 food cards (with a number value on it), if he succeeds while the mouse in on its way back to the hole, both players get a food card, and if the mouse reaches the hole, the "mouse player" gets 2 food cards. The winner is the player with the highest total on his/her food cards.

Name: Word In Progress
Description: Word in Progress is a sort of word game which turns the methodology of building complete words, as is found in word games such as Scrabble or Boggle, on its head.  In Word in Progress, players must work together to build partial words without being the player to complete an actual word, all the while attempting to discard as many of their respective points (letters) as possible before being eliminated from the round of play.

Name: 50 Card Games for Children
Description:
From the front cover text:

Complete rules for easy games that are fun to play for one or more players. Plus card tricks and beginners' Contract Bridge.

Name: Warhammer 40,000: Cities of Death
Description:
(From Games Workshop Website)


    The Cities of Death expansion to Warhammer 40,000 (Fourth Edition) and Warhammer 40,000 (Fifth Edition) introduces rules that let you engage in bitter struggles amid the deadly city streets of the 41st millennium. Also included are modeling tips, painting secrets, scenarios and much, much more.*


Cities of Death gives the players the opportunity to play Skirmish style game play, similar to what Mordheim is to Warhammer Fantasy Battles. There is a new line of city ruin Terrain sold through Games Workshop for Cities of Death.

Requires Warhammer 40K or The Battle for Macragge to play.

Expands:

    Warhammer 40,000 (Fourth Edition)
    Warhammer 40,000: Battle for Macragge
    Warhammer 40,000 (Fifth Edition)

Name: Knights of the Round Table
Description:
A sort of a proto-RPG using miniatures, set in the world of "Le Morte d'Arthur," which can be used to fight stand-alone melees, or to play extended campaigns.

Included are:
-rules for 1 on 1 melees and jousts that involves choosing cards representing various attacks or defenses.  Percentage dice are used to determine combat results, your chance to hit being determined by your and your opponent's choice of card.  The severity of the result is determined by the amount which your roll exceeds the base chance to hit

-simplified rules for combats involving multiple combatants

-rules for limited campaigns(lasting a few hours) and for longer campaigns of perhaps indefinite length.  The extended ("full") campaign includes rules for warfare and conquest and enable players to play enchanters as well as knights.  There are encounter tables and many rules designed to capture the flavor of the Arthurian mythos.
Families: Theme: King Arthur / The Knights of the Round Table / Camelot

Name: Jeux de pions pour aujourd'hui
Description:
Jeux de pions pour aujourd'hui is a set of laminated cardstock game boards, stickers for placing on pieces (not supplied, but easy to find or improvise), and an activity book containing historical flavor text in French and rules in both French and English, all packaged in a clear plastic pouch. The game boards, sticker sheets and rules included in the set are:

Agon / Queen's Guards
Le canard Marseillais / The Duck from Marseilles
Jeu de la chasse au loup / Wolf Hunt
Jeu des chasseurs / The Hunters
Le jeu du cirque / Circus
Jeu du Congo / Congo
Foot-ball lil-i-put / Lilliputian Soccer
Jeu des grenouilles / Frogs
Jeu des quatrarmes / Quaterarms
Salta / Salta
Le tacticien / The Tactician
Le voyage à Pékin / Trip to Beijing

Ce fichier contient différents types de documents.

Un livret de 42 pages donnant les règles des 12 jeux de pions, en français et en anglais, avec de nombreux diagrammes qui facilitent la compréhension. La première partie du livret situe ces jeux dans leur contexte historique et donne un aperçu du monde des jeux de pions en ce début de XXI siècle : centres de vacances collectives, à l'école, en famille.

Douze tabliers cartonnés correspondant à 12 jeux de pions édités en France, la plupart au début du XX, à la Belle Époque : l'Agon, Le canard Marseillais, Jeu de la chasse au loup, Jeu des chasseurs, Le jeu du cirque, Jeu du Congo, Foot-ball lil-i-put, Jeu des grenouilles, Jeu des quatrarmes, Salta, Le tacticien, Le voyage à Pékin.

Des planches de figurines autocollantes et prédécoupées : dé spécial, pions et cartes.

Name: Goola
Description:
Goola is a advanced adaptation of "Connect Four" with some twists.  Players alternately drop one of their twenty "Goola" beads into one of the five slots in the Goola Tower trying to form a line of 4 or 5 beads of their color in order to accumulate points (1 point for a line of 4 and 2 points for a line of 5).  The twist here is that scoring only happens after all the beads are placed.  After the initial placement, each player then alternately operate one of the five mechanic valves at the bottom of the tower under each slot to make the beads drop one by one out the bottom of the tower.  After each bead drops out, each player count all the points they get for forming lines of 4 or 5 beads of the same color. The player with the higher points scores the difference in points on the scoreboard.  The first player to reach 8 points on the scoreboard wins.  A further twist can be found in the blind-play option built in the Goola Tower.  This advance play is similar to the basic game except that the bead placement is shielded from the players' sight, and the players must reply on memory to calculate where to place their beads.  After all the beads are played, the lock mechanism is released allowing the beads to drop into sight and the game continues as normal.

Game components:
40 Goola beads in two colors
1 Goola tower
1 Tower base with scoreboard
2 Goola stickers
1 Rulebook

Name: Empire
Description:
H.G. Wells Awards for "Best All-Time Napoleonic Rules" and "Hall of Fame

Gold Hot-Stamped Imperial Green Leatherette 3-Ring Binder
Over 100 pages of rules and designer notes with numerous pages of reference material specifying leader ratings, troop-types, and much more.

Colorful die-cut counters for orders, unit status and terrain aids.

6 color-coded reference charts for easy access to important tables of play.

1 fold-out elan chart

Name: ClimbingMan
Description:
Reach the top of the rock wall to complete this solitaire game, which uses a standard piecepack. In the game, you control the climber's hands and feet and also the position of the body in relation to the extremities. Find a way to move upwards choosing spots that are strong enough to support your weight.

The tiles make up the wall and the coins (suit up) the spots you can hold on to. 4 dice represent your 4 extremities and a pawn your "center of gravity". When you place an extremity in a spot you can hold on to, you flip the coin and it shows the maximum weight it can support. In addition, the farther an extremity is from the "center of gravity" the less weight it can support too. After moving the die to the new spot, you place it showing the weight it supports. The trick is to support your whole weight between the 4 extremities. Then, move your center of gravity to a new position where you can reach newer spots, finding your way through the wall.

Name: ABC Lotto
Description:
One child alone will enjoy playing the game as a puzzle by trying to match up the small cards with the pictures on the boards. This type of play will help develop one of the basic skills necessary in learning to read.

FOR GROUP PLAY... each child takes one of the boards. The small cards are mixed up thoroughly and placed face down in the middle of the table.

The child to the left of the one who mixed the cards is the first to go and picks any card in the pile. If the card matches a section of his board, he places it over the matching illustration and has the privilege of picking the next cards also. This same player continues to pick cards until he reaches on that does not match his board. If one of the other players needs this card, he calls for it and also continues to pick and match as did the previous player. If no one needs the card picked, it is turned face down again and the child to the left of the last player is the next to go.

The play continues around the group until one child has all the sections of his board covered with the matching cards and is declared the winner.

Before playing a new game the boards are interchanged among the players.

Name: Jubilee
Description:
A really quirky Red, White & Blue capture & replacement game (no points are scored) where the winner is the first player to have all his men in play on the board, however this is achieved.

In this game the player’s men are called Purim.

Once laid the Purim are neither ‘jumped’ or moved - but may be ‘returned to that player’s pot’. The key to this game is ‘Red, White, Blue. Red, White, Blue,,,etc’. Remember that & you cant go wrong. Recommended Ages 7+

Name: Troy
Description:
For 2 to 4 players played on the intersections of the board where the winner is the player with the most points at the end of the game.

In this game the players men are called Sheckles.

With all of the Sheckle belonging to all of the players you play with as many Sheckles as you like to make a set, then play with as many sets as you like to build your armies. Troy is played in ‘waves’, with points scored by catch-trapping Sheckles that are ‘in-play’ which, if not saved, make up that players next wave; So although saving is not obligatory you’ll soon regret it if you don't! Enjoy. Recommended Ages 9+

Name: Pedrek
Description:
The Cornish word for 'square', for 2 to many more players where the winner is the first player to complete a circuit of their score card, called their ‘Table card’.

In this game the players men are called Dan.

The sets themselves are made up of either:

a (A) set; Red, Yellow, Blue & Purple cards; Or

a (B) set; Black, White, Green & Brown cards.

Therefore with the adding together of further sets, e.g. 2 (A) sets, this would be a 2 to 4 player game with up to twenty-four Dan per player; or with the adding together of an (A) & a (B) set this would give a game for 2 to 8 players, with up to 12 Dan per player: Etc. There is no limit to how many sets can be added together to make a bigger and bigger game! Cracking. Recommended Ages 9+

Name: Gammot
Description:
My only variation game, this is a true 4 player Backgammon game, not a team game, but for 4 individual players. Not only is it a great game for those that already know backgammon but it also makes a great conversation piece set up on the coffee table.

There's a couple difference from the original in the set up rules and the throw rules; & there's also a nice little rule of my own thrown in that you might like to play. Recommended Ages 9+

Name: Bionicle: The Quest Game
Description:
The evil Piraka have invaded the island of Voya Nui and are now on the hunt for the powerful Mask of Life. Take up the Toa Inika mission to find the Mask before the Piraka. Traverse the island carefully, and be ready to do battle along the way.

Includes six exclusive collectible Toa Inika game pieces, a double-sided game board, a Protodermis ball launcher with Zamor sphere, a Piraka target, 50 Quest cards, and a die.

Name: Pictionary: Salem Holiday
Description:
This appears to be a game issued by R.J. Reynolds.  The use of Salem Holiday Edition on the box indicates it was sold as a promotional item (I assume with Salem cigarettes).

It comes in a small box (approximately 5 by 7 inches).  The following items are included:

- A small gameboard (6 by 9 inches).  The gameboard folds out and inside the directions for play are printed.  There are also a small number of paper sheets stapled on the interior gameboard.
- A small die
- 4 pawns
- 2 pencils
- A small pack of 20 cards.

Name: Gorram Reavers!
Description: Players are parts of Reaver packs from Joss Whedon's "Firefly" universe. The goal is to raid planets and moons for victims. Winner is the first player to a 1000 body count. The board is a variable lay out of planets and moons with chits on them representing populations to ravage. Players move their ships from location to location and trying to over power what they find. Players use cards to increase their crew "packs" and give them bonuses as well as cards that effect the 'verse and other players. Players can upgrade ships to carry bigger crews.

Name: Keep Flyin'
Description:
From the rules:
In Keep Flyin, you are the Captain of a Firefly class mid-bulk transport, trying to eke out a living by taking any jobs you can find, legit or not, do them, and get paid. All the while you will be avoiding the oppressive governing body known as the Alliance, the terrifying Reavers who seek to eat you, and various other local color in the ‘Verse. You will find jobs on planets and even in the deepest parts of the Black. So find a job, don’t care much what it is, and keep flyin’.

Players move from planet to planet looking for jobs and searching abandoned ships. Players then move potential enemy ships, (Alliance or Reavers) after opponent's ships. has mechanic for pursuit and battle is dice based. First player to raise enough money to retire wins.

Home Page: http://users.adelphia.net/~wydraz/firefly/keepflyin.html

Name: BWAH!
Description:
A fan-made re-theme of BANG!, based on Joss Whedon's "Firefly" TV show. Instead of Sheriff, Deputy, Outlaw and Renegade, it's Captain, Crew, Local Color and The Merc. Characters are from the TV show, such as Wash, Mal, Book, Zoe, River, etc. Weapons and everything else is also based on the show; i.e. Vera (Weapon) and the Mule (Vehicle instead of Mount). And instead of Beer, you get Mudder's Milk.

Expanded by:


     BWAH!: Gorram Plans
     BWAH!: This Land 
     BWAH!: Local Color   
     BWAH! Can't Stop the Signal (Also plays as separate base game) 
     BWAH!: Those Left Behind  


Currently Active Download Links:


     http://www.fireflyfans.net/mthread.aspx?bid=13&tid=36208&mid=664346#664346
     http://jonathan.kc8onw.net/TCM%20Firefly%20Games/

Name: Die vier Jahreszeiten
Description: "The Four Seasons" is a simple children's set-collection game. Twenty-eight wooden tiles with illustrations of scenes from the four seasons are arranged into a square of five on a side with the remaining tiles forming a pile in the center. Four "season children", each in a different color representing one of the seasons, are placed on the track. Players try to collect one card from each of the seasons by moving any one of the four children the number shown on the die. If a child lands on a season tile of the same color that player may keep it. The first player to collect one tile from each season wins.

Name: Take Two!
Description:
From the Box:

"Take Two! is a fun-filled game for 2 or more that's a new game every time you play.  Arrange tiles randomly on the board, then start grabbing.  Everyone plays at once, grabbing matched pairs off the ends of the rows until the board is empty.  Whoever has the most matched pairs wins.  But choose carefully--and take a second look, because some pieces look almost alike.  If just one pair is mismatched, you lose."

This is best described as multi-player version of Mah Jong (solitaire version). It has a very frantic pace as everyone races to grab tiles.  Comes with a board with affixed plastic rows to keep the tiles in line, and 124 domino quality tiles.

Name: Slumber Party
Description:
One in a series of sixteen Flipsiders games designed to resemble pastel colored audio cassettes. The game contained a metal gameboard that would flip out with the snap of the wrist. A storage compartment at the top of the game would hold the magnetic pawns. A spring-loaded switch would spin the wheels of the cassette to generate random numbers and events during play. The game would hang from a blister pack on display at the store.

Every time you hit your opponent she gets closer to bedtime. The object is to stall bedtime as long as possible.

Name: Alien Assault
Description:
One in a series of sixteen Flipsiders games designed to resemble pastel colored audio cassettes. The game contained a metal gameboard that would flip out with the snap of the wrist. A storage compartment at the top of the game would hold the magnetic pawns. A spring-loaded switch would spin the wheels of the cassette to generate random numbers and events during play. The game would hang from a blister pack on display at the store.

Players must advance toward and defeat in battle the boss alien on three levels to win. Defeat means starting a level all over again.

Name: Caterpillar Causeway
Description:
One in a series of sixteen Flipsiders games designed to resemble pastel colored audio cassettes. The game contained a metal gameboard that would flip out with the snap of the wrist. A storage compartment at the top of the game would hold the magnetic pawns. A spring-loaded switch would spin the wheels of the cassette to generate random numbers and events during play. The game would hang from a blister pack on display at the store.

Chute and Ladders (AKA Snakes and Ladders) adapted to fit the Flipsiders format.

Name: Gold Fever
Description:
One in a series of sixteen Flipsiders games designed to resemble pastel colored audio cassettes. The game contained a metal gameboard that would flip out with the snap of the wrist. A storage compartment at the top of the game would hold the magnetic pawns. A spring-loaded switch would spin the wheels of the cassette to generate random numbers and events during play. The game would hang from a blister pack on display at the store.

The left spinner tells how far the players may advance during a turn. The right spinner tells the player whether or not one may advance when one reaches a barrier. The first to complete four trips through the mine is the winner.

Name: Prized Pony
Description:
One in a series of sixteen Flipsiders games designed to resemble pastel colored audio cassettes. The game contained a metal gameboard that would flip out with the snap of the wrist. A storage compartment at the top of the game would hold the magnetic pawns. A spring-loaded switch would spin the wheels of the cassette to generate random numbers and events during play. The game would hang from a blister pack on display at the store.

Players take turns using the right spinner to advance their board marker. When a player reaches a jump, the player must use the left spinner to determine if the jump is successful. The winner is the first player to complete all four rounds of the steeplechase.

Name: River Run
Description:
One in a series of sixteen Flipsiders games designed to resemble pastel colored audio cassettes. The game contained a metal gameboard that would flip out with the snap of the wrist. A storage compartment at the top of the game would hold the magnetic pawns. A spring-loaded switch would spin the wheels of the cassette to generate random numbers and events during play. The game would hang from a blister pack on display at the store.

The left spinner is used to indicate upstream and downstream movement. The right spinner is used to indicate distance moved. The first player to reach the finish line is the winner.

Name: Sweet and Sour: The Chinese Restaurant Game
Description: A dexterity game that requires the players to use chopsticks to move small pieces around.

Name: BWAH!: Gorram Plans
Description:
Expansion for BWAH!! the BANG!! based card game set in the "Firefly" Universe. This expansion allows for up to 11 players as well as contains options rules and Episode cards based on the different episodes of the show. These cards have a wide range of effects. Optional rules include cards based on the shows gag reel, its cancellation by Fox and its movie deal. Rules for a 2 or 3 person game are included as well.

Expands:

    BWAH!

Name: BWAH!: Local Color
Description:
Another expansion for BWAH!! which is based on the game BANG!! set in the "Firefly" Universe. This one includes 18 new characters and 18 new actions cards as well as rule and card clarification.

Expands:

    BWAH!

Name: BWAH!: This Land
Description:
A very small expansion for BWAH!! which is based on the game BANG!! but set in the "Firefly" universe. Based on a short bit by one character in the first episode of the show this set add 3 characters, 2 are plastic dinos and the other is a new Wash card. Also there are a 2 new action cards, a new location and a new episode card.

Expands:

    BWAH!

Name: BWAH! Can't Stop the Signal
Description: A stand alone BWAH!! game that can be combined with the original if desired. BWAH! Can't Stop the Signal is based on the game BANG!! but set in the "Firefly" universe created by Joss Whedon. This one is based on the movie "Serenity" and not directly the show. The game uses the same mechanics as BWAH! and BANG! except the characters and professions are from the movie. Some examples are Wash, Zoe, and Mal as characters and Psychic, Crew, Captain, Reavers, and Operative as professions. Health is recovered by eating Fruity Oaty Bars.

Name: Bloodbath at the Sakarya, August, 1921
Description:
BLOODBATH simulates the horrific, turning point, battle in the Greek attack towards Ankara in August, 1921. The Greek Army had been unstoppable up to now and the Turks were reeling back to the last stand defenses in the hills just across the Sakarya River. Their morale had taken a serious blow, so serious, that orders were to shoot any Turk soldier caught fleeing during the battle. The Greeks paused for two weeks before advancing across the river, giving the Turks time to build a two lines of defenses. Greek divisions averaged 10,000 men, while Turk divisions averaged 5000. Both sides were feeling the pinch of supply issues, both quite determined to crush the other. If the Greeks won, Ankara, Turkey's new capitol, would fall and perhaps part of Turkey would become part of Greece. The battle and war all reached this pivotal situation, critical to both sides. It would be bloody--over 18,000 died on the hills from August 23 to 30.

Game scale: 12 hr. turns, battalions. Each hex is around 400 yds. Owners of The Great Attack 1922 will easily assimilate the rules, although there are some new ones to learn.

The game comes with one 11x17 inch map, 280 counters and rulebook.

Related game:
Bir Buyuk Turk Saldiri

Name: Arclight: Close Encounters in Nearspace
Description:
Expansion to the base Arclight game with a focus on the creatures that inhabit space.

Expands:

    Arclight

Name: Mississippi -- The Speed Boat Race
Description: A simple spin and move game on the Mississippi River.  The speedboat pieces are kind of nice, but the massive, upright roulette style spinner is the highlight of the game.

Name: Trivial Pursuit Mini Pack: Sports
Description: This Mini or Pocket Pack was made for use with the Trivial Pursuit Pocket Player Set Game but also featured color coded questions for use with the regular Trivial Pursuit games.  This set contains 120 sports themed cards: "From baseball to bullfighting - With an emphasis on recent times."

Name: Hunters in the Sky: Aerial Combat in Second World War
Description:
Hunters in the Sky is a complete miniatures game of WWII air combat. The basic rules allow for relatively large battles with up to a dozen aircraft per side and minimal record keeping.

Optional rules are included which cover; air to ground combat, bombers (dive, level and torpedo), variable pilot quality and experience, and simple campaign system.

Advanced rules which add realism include; advanced maneuvering, deflection shooting, visual spotting, limited ammunition, critical damage, and more...

Also included is the Warbirds aircraft lists, with game stats for 118 different aircraft from 10 different nations.
28 pages.

"Hunters in the sky is by far the best WWII aircraft game I have ever played! If you do not have this in your collection then SHAME ON YOU! BUY IT NOW!"  -  R.A. June 2006

Download version can be purchased at www.wargamedownloads.com

Name: Special Forces
Description:
Counter-Terrorist Warfare in the Modern Age

Special Forces is a miniatures game of close combat in the modern era. Inspired by first-person shooter computer games such as Delta Force and Rainbow Six, he rules are designed for small scale battles with one or two dozen figures per side.

Special Forces is easy to learn and fast playing, with an emphasis on playability. It includes rules for infantry action and vehicles and comes with two sample scenarios; Columbian Crack-Down and Hostage Rescue - Iraq.

13 pages

Download version can be found at www.wargamedownloads.com

Name: McWiz Junior
Description:
From Dr. Toy:

"There are 1,200 questions included in this innovative game. It is available in French and English. This game is perfect for children 6 and over. There are three questions on each card: one is aimed at younger children (6-7 yrs.) the second aimed for older(8-9 yrs) and the third aimed for 10 to 12 years old children. Everyone at all ages can play the game together. The first player or team to complete the jigsaw puzzle wins. Most questions are based on actual school textbooks."

Expanded by:

    McWiz Junior Booster Bus: The Bus of Knowledge in Math

Name: Amazing Animal Trivia Game
Description:
From Dr. Toy:

"This game allows children to delve into the world of animals and will fascinate them for a long time. Children can collect sets of cards. There are 200 multiple choice and true/false trivia questions. In order to have a turn, you must correctly answer on the card drawn. Excellent graphics on each card make the animals sharp and interesting to look at."

Name: Word for Word Reading Rods
Description:
From Discovery Toys:

"In a fast-paced race against the clock, build as many words as you can and strengthen phonics and spelling skills. Players at different reading levels can play at the same time using specified combinations of colored rods. Or practice with basic word families, rhyming words and blended sounds at your own pace with the included activity book (used in schools to teach reading). Especially helpful for kinesthetic and visual learners."

Name: Fractions Supreme Pizza Game
Description:
From Discovery Toys:

"Pizza parts make a "whole" lot of fun. Help children visualize and understand the concept of fractions, using a favorite food and a fun strategy game. Game variations challenge players to master fraction equivalencies, addition and more."

Name: Wildlife Bingo Game
Description:
The first matching game using wildlife photos which were taken directly from DK's best selling children's books.

Classic bingo is only one of the variations which are described in the rules pamphlet, as young players are challenged to work on matching, sorting, and language skills

A perfect first game for the children...

Name: Mens erger je niet!: Kaartspel
Description:
Card version roughly simulating the endgame situation in vanilla "Mens erger je niet!" / "Ne t'en fais pas!" (a "Pachisi" / "Parcheesi" clone), the object being to 'bring the pawns home'.

Each player has an identical pack of 24 cards, in one of 4 colors. There are 4 sets of 6 cards with each set having a die value printed on the cards: 1 through 4. The cards within a set have a number of colored pawns on them, 1 through 6, and have to be played onto their 'home' pile in that order.

The object is to play out all your cards onto the 4 'home' piles while hampering your opponent.

Card play is done "Shut the box" style, where the eyes on a standard D6 determine the total value of cards that may be played onto their 'home' piles. A [6] rolled allows for another die roll and play of cards.
The pawns printed on the cards come into play when hampering the opponent. When one of the 'home' piles -represented by the dice- reaches the same size -represented by the pawns- as the opponent's identical pile, the opponent has to empty that 'home' pile.

Winner is the player who 'brings all pawns home' first.

Name: Stargo
Description:
From the Rules of Play:

STARGO is a fun and engaging way to introduce kids to the basic concepts of stars, galaxies and constellations. There are two ways to play, and both are based on Bingo. Version "A" uses basic number and color concepts as players search for stars on one constellation. Version "B" uses basic visual and memory skills as players enjoy traditional Bingo on a grid featuring 24 constellations.

				
				
					Version A:

There are 30 large glossy cards, each featuring a constellation with numbered, colored stars (that glow in the dark!). Each player selects one. Colored and numbered stars are selected from the bag and called -- first to complete his constellation wins.

Version B:

On the flip side of the constellation cards is a traditional Bingo grid of constellations. Constellations are selected from a deck (each has information about that constellation on the back). First to complete five in a row wins.

				
				
					The constellation cards feature glow in the dark stars and an orienting arrow. Combined with the included compass, they can be used to help find those constellations in the night sky. The smaller cards contain facts about the constellations and the stars within them. The rulebook also contains information about stargazing.

Name: Road Rally
Description:
One in a series of sixteen Flipsiders games designed to resemble pastel colored audio cassettes. The game contained a metal gameboard that would flip out with the snap of the wrist. A storage compartment at the top of the game would hold the magnetic pawns. A spring-loaded switch would spin the wheels of the cassette to generate random numbers and events during play. The game would hang from a blister pack on display at the store.

The spinners determine how far one may move during one’s turn. The players will compete in three races and the first to complete all three races is the winner.

Name: Die Angelschlacht 1944
Description:
Die Angelschlacht (the pivotal battle) 1944 covers the 25th SS PG\12SS Panzer division's counterattack on June 7th against the strung out Canadian forces west of Caen. The 12thSS struck with 45 tanks and quickly advanced causing a panic to the allies. The Canadians had little armor and were out of artillery range. The battle lasted 6 hours and the SS advanced only a few miles but this attack delayed the allied advance for another 30 days! The game has over 280 counters and one 11x17" map, rulebook. Include in the game are unique random events that makes game play never the same. For those interested in historical or what games, player's may choose to do either. The game contains many scenarios.

Each hex is 200-250 yds, each turn is 30 min. Units are company level, each with a morale and movement rating. Actual fire strengths depend on the unit firing, type of attack, range to target, and weapon firing. New rules cover random events, anti-aircraft fire, air units, M10's, Panther tanks.

Name: The Dvina River Offensive: Final Blows in North Russia, August 1919
Description:
By August 1919, the British 45th and 46th Battalions, together with over seven river monitors and gunboats mounting up to 9" guns, over 25 aircraft (mostly DH9A bombers) were in place for the final blow on the Red virus known as Bolshevism. By this time, the French and Americans had all left. It was now a British show and one that was destined to leave a bloody nose upon the Reds. At least that was the plan! As the troops gathered along both sides of the Dvina River (the river was very large), the opposing forces were as determined. The Reds fielded the 3rd Brigade\18th Division amounting to the 160, 161, 162 Regiments, numerous large artillery barges, six fighter aircraft, many gunboats, lots of mines, trenches. The overconfident British had not factored in the effects of Mother Nature, which as the battle wore on, smiled too often on the Red forces. Clearing BOTH sides of this major river ( think Mississippi) and advancing hundreds of miles to Kotlas (the main Red base) in hindsight, seemed like a crazy idea, but at the time, was a tempting objective. And so it was. The Dvina River Offensive had it all: dogfighting aircraft, ground combat, naval surface action, naval bombardment, bombing, machine guns, artillery, river monitors and gunboats, unpredictable river currents, water levels, sandbars, floating mines sent down by the Reds, foul weather, balloons. The offensive lasted four days. One part went extraordinarily well-another part nosedived into hell-both sides get to enjoy this game!

Game scale is 750 yds a hex, turns are 12 hrs, 10 in all. Ground units are platoons, artillery batteries, single aircraft include: Sopwith, Spad, Avro, DH9A, Re 8, Neuiport, M20 and Short. River ships include: monitors, gunboats, each representing one ship. Ground units include Lewis guns, MG, Stokes mortars, leaders, infantry. There are two game maps, one covers the ground action and the other the air to air combat at a different scale (50 yd a hex). Aircraft are rated for speed, bombing, size, maneuver, altitude. Thus, the game is really two games: an operational ground game, a tactical naval and air to air combat game!

Name: Perry Rhodan Simulation
Description:
Rare German Space Battle System based on the famous German Sci-Fi Novels.

Ever wanted to take a seat behind the command panel of the battleship STARDUST and personally lead the pride of the Terran Navy into battle? Now it is possible.

The first in a series of games based on the world-renowned Perry Rhodan series - the space combat system! A new, easy-to-use control system enables a "realistic" and detailed simulation of events that are typical of a battle in the endless expanses of space. You can decide for yourself whether two individual ships should fight a duel or whether whole formations should collide, and otherwise you are the one who makes the decisions.

Tactical movement, deceleration or acceleration, short transition or emergency jump, volleys, point fire or full broadside, everything is in your hands. The game material you have at your disposal is a playing surface measuring 59 x 42 cm, a rule book, a scenario book, a set of data sheets, 56 pages of background material, 180 game pieces and two twenty-sided dice.


Wollten Sie schon immer einmal hinter dem Kommandopult des Schlachtschiffes STARDUST Platz nehmen und den Stolz der terranischen Raumflotte persönlich ins Gefecht führen? Jetzt ist es möglich.

Als erstes einer Reihe von Spielen mit dem Hintergrund der weltbekannten Perry Rhodan-Serie erhältlich - das Raumkampfsystem! Ein neuartiges, leicht zu handhabendes Regelsystem ermöglicht eine "realistische" und detailgetreue Simulation von Geschehnissen, wie sie für ein Gefecht in den endlosen Weiten des Weltraums typisch sind. Ob zwei einzelne Raumer ein Duell miteinander ausfechten oder ganze Verbände aufeinander prallen sollen, können Sie selbst entscheiden, und auch sonst sind Sie es, der die Entscheidungen trifft..

Taktische Bewegung, Abbremsen oder Beschleunigen, Kurztransition oder Notsprung, Salven, Punktfeuer oder volle Breitseite, alles lieggt in Ihrer Hand. Als Spielmaterial steht Ihnen dabei eine Spielfläche von 59 x 42 cm, ein Regelband, ein Szenarioband, ein Satz Datenblätter, 56 Seiten Hintergrundmaterial, 180 Spielsteine und zwei zwanzigseitige Würfel zur Verfügung."

Name: Escape from Chosin: Toktong Pass 1950
Description:
Critical Hit's newest Advanced Squad Leader compatible game extension covers the fighting in Korea in 1950.

Contents include:
Two sheets of die-cut variant counters, representing all the SMC and MMC counters, plus AFVs and guns, that you will need to play the game IN NEW FULL COLOR FORMAT, including CCF Buglers, grenade squads, USMC in Winter Uniforms, and much more; 
A large historical game map on heavyweight stock; 
8 scenarios printed on cardstock
PLUS TWO BONUS scenarios 
VARIANT Rules and a PLATOON LEADER campaign game; 
 The scenarios and CG are fought on a colorful map depicting the rugged terrain found on the Korean Peninsula. This expansion is the first of Critical Hit's products to feature full color counters.

This is not a stand alone game. You must have the ASL Rulebook and any other ASL module (Beyond Valor) for the necessary game markers in order to play.

Visit www.criticalhit.com for more information

Name: Switch
Description: Switch is the first of the small box games published by Pseudon and is noted with "#1" on the spine. The game includes 16 tiles which are first laid out for all to see. The tiles are then flipped, and in turn a player must flip two to find the scoring combinations on the score sheet. The winner of the game is the first to make all the combinations on their score sheet.

Name: Retire-E-Z-Z-Z
Description:
"A New Twist to the Popular Card Game Hearts!" boasts the cover.  The game is somewhat of a Hearts with a retirement theme, but there are some rule ambiguities that make it unclear.  There are 40 cards, 10 each in 4 suits.  The black & white artwork on each card depicts various advantages to retirement (more time, relaxation, etc.)  The lead player lays down a card.  Players must follow suit if possible, but also "always trying to get red of heart cards first". It is not clear if this is a rule or strategic advice.

The person who plays the "highest card in the group" wins, but it is not clear if group refers to cards which followed suit or all cards played. Later, the rules indicate that players could have different numbers of cards in their hand, and that the game ends when one player is out. This seems to indicate that the proper interpretation of the rule that the winner "takes the hand" is that the winner takes the cards from the trick into their hand.

All cards left in players hands are worth face value, except hearts are worth 10 each. The person with the least points - at the end of one hand is the winner.

Neither the rules nor the box specify the player count range.

Name: Captain Morgan's Wrath
Description: Captain Morgan's Wrath is the pirate drinking game by Party Hard Corps. Spinning a tee-totum (think a dreidel), the players are encouraged to be as loud with their yaaaaars as possible while the it spins, or even bang on the table to try to make a player "walk the plank!" First player with five doubloons and the captain's patch is the commodore, and the winner- unless the crew mutinies, and leaves that land lubber on an uncharted island!

Name: Cult
Description: Cult: The Drinking Game of Politics in an Esoteric Order is the first game by Party Hard Corps. The players take on the roles of cultists in an occult group, vying for political influence on their way to illumination. One player, the Messiah- whose signifying ring could be passed on at any turn- gets to declare what the cult worships (and therefore what rules are in play). A party game of fast drinking and fast dice rolling.

Name: Agribizz
Description: Players begin with 4,000 dollars and have the chance to make a fortune or go broke by investing in farms and farm related businesses. A property can be purchased only by landing on it and each time a player must decide whether to invest his limited funds or to hope for something better among the 28 farms and 9 businesses available along the track. Cheaper properties are easier to develop but have a smaller payoff when landed on by an opponent. (just like Monopoly). Another decision must be made regarding the 3 different kinds of crops that may be planted on each farm. Again cheaper pays off sooner but in smaller amounts. Once the crop is in a player can add farm equipment in the form of plastic "silo sections" which are piled in strict color sequence. Limited quantities of the best crops and the highest silo section adds to the decision making process. A player may mortgage a property to pay debt or to make other investments and can still collect 10% of his normal fee from a visiting opponent. Other features include taxes, becoming incorporated, luck cards which can be disastrous, selling properties to an opponent or the treasury.

Name: Scrabble Junior: Wildlife
Description:
From Dr. Toy

"This game incorporates the traditional Scrabble Jr. game, but is played like a crossword puzzle, featuring baby animals and wildlife found in National Parks. Kid-sized words and colorful pictures of animals make it fun to match letter tiles to words on two playful crossword grids. One side features wildlife, while the other side features the environment included is an endangered animal coloring book featuring facts about endangered wildlife."

Name: Zodiac Match
Description: This game features 96 "domino" tiles, consisting of different pairings of the 12 zodiac symbols. Each symbol appears red and black. Twelve of the tiles have stars at one end and are "wild". 2 to 4 players play, each using a rack of 6 tiles. Tiles can be placed anywhere in the layout provided that they match the same symbol in opposite color of at least one face that has been previously played. Notches on the tiles help keep the layout securely in place. The score for a play depends on the number of matches which, in rare cases, can be as many as 6. If a player can make a match on at least one face of his tile he may play a second or third and so on up to all 6 tiles from his hand. Play ends when, after all the tiles have been drawn a player clears his rack, earning a bonus. High score wins

Name: Inspiration
Description:
Inspiration is one of Wolfgang Kramer’s not so well-known games, which he designed together with his wife Ursula. It is a party game in the vein of Taboo or Activity, although the players do not paraphrase terms or play charades. Rather, the players try to solve picture puzzles faster than their opponents. In each round, one of the players acts as the moderator and chooses two picture cards, that together represent a two part noun (e.g. ball game (cards 73 and 20) or treasure chamber (cards 54 and 104)). The player may choose between asking an easy, medium or difficult question. Then the other players try to solve the puzzle, while a sand timer runs down. Depending on the difficulty, the player who calls out the correct answer first, may advance 2, 3, or 4 spaces on the track.  The first player to reach the goal is the winner. 
Inspiration features a clever card index box, to keep the picture cards organized and two bookmarks to quickly find where to put back the previously selected cards.

Name: Millennium: Das Jahrtausendspiel
Description:
“Millennium – the millennium game” (as it would be literally - and rather silly - translated into English) is a memory game with a twist meets a historical trivia game. The game board shows an event, an important person or anything characteristic for each decade from 10 to 2000 (with the exception of 500, 1000 and 1500) represented in nice comic art as well as text and arranged in a huge spiral covering almost the complete board.
At the beginning of the game, the players cover 10 of the decades one by one with cardboard disks numbered from 1 to 10, while reading out the year and the accompanying text. E.g. “10 Emperor Augustus”, “1060 William the Conqueror”, “1190 The third Crusade” or “1770 The USA”. 
Each player then gets ten transparent plastic chips. The goal of the game is to get rid of these chips by correctly remembering the events etc. under the numbered cardboard disks. In each turn, initially the player rolls a d12. Then he has to repeat the decade and the text under the corresponding disk. Only if he succeeds, he may return one chip to the box and replace the disk on a new decade; in any case, the next player gets to roll the die. The 11 and 12 on the die have special functions:
When rolling 11, the player may place one of his chips on a cardboard disk of his choice. The next player who rolls the corresponding number has to take this chip before trying to remember what is underneath.
When rolling 12, the player asks the player with the most chips left to remember what is under a disk of his choice. If the other player succeeds, he may place one of his chips on the disk and replace the disk, otherwise, the first player has to solve the task. If he does not succeed either, the player with the most chips may give him one of his chips.
Apart from the material described, Millennium contains a small almanac (30 pg.) with a short description of each decades event, person etc.

Name: Script
Description: Script is the third of the small box games published by Pseudon and is noted with "#3" on the spine, and it is a word game. The game consists of a set of letter tiles each with a number, as in Scrabble. The unique thing about the game is that over the course of the game players must come up with 20 words each beginning with a different letter of the alphabet, and all the words must be different.
